Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some are longer than a blue whale. Others are barely larger 
than a grain of sand. One species unleashes one of
the most deadly venoms on Earth. Another holds a secret that's behind some 
of the greatest breakthroughs in biology. They've inhabited the ocean for at least
half a billion years, and they're still flourishing as the sea
changes around them. Jellyfish are soft-bodied sea creatures
that aren't really fish. They're part of a diverse team
of gelatinous zooplankton, zooplankton being animals that drift
in the ocean. There are more than 1,000 species
of jellyfish, and many others 
that are often mistaken for them. A noted feature of jellyfish 
is a translucent bell made of a soft delicate material
called mesoglea. Sandwiched between two layers of skin, the mesoglea is more than 95% water
held together by protein fibers. The jellyfish can contract and 
relax their bells to propel themselves. They don't have a brain or a spinal cord, but a neural net around the bell's
inner margin forms a rudimentary nervous system that can sense the ocean's currents
and the touch of other animals. Jellyfish don't have typical 
digestive systems, either. These gelatinous carnivores consume 
plankton and other small sea creatures through a hole in the underside 
of their bells. The nutrients are absorbed by
an inner layer of cells with waste excreted back through
their mouths. But the jellyfish's relatively 
simple anatomy doesn't prevent it from having
some remarkable abilities. One kind of box jellyfish has 24 eyes. Scientists think it can see color and form
images within its simple nervous system. Four of its eyes are curved 
upward on stalks. This allows the jellyfish to peer
through the surface of the water, looking for the canopy 
of the mangrove trees where it feeds. In fact, this may be one 
of the only creatures with a 360-degree view of its environment. The jellyfish's sting, which helps it
capture prey and defend itself, is its most infamous calling card. In the jelly's epidermis, cells called nematocysts
lie coiled like poisonous harpoons. When they're triggered by contact,
they shoot with an explosive force. It exerts over 550 times the pressure
of Mike Tyson's strongest punch to inject venom into the victim. Some jellyfish stings barely tingle, but others cause severe skin damage. The venom of one box jellyfish
can kill a human in under five minutes, making it one of the most potent
poisons of any animal in the world. Other jellyfish superpowers 
are less lethal. One species of jellyfish glows green
when it's agitated, mostly thanks to a biofluorescent compound
called green fluorescent protein, or GFP. Scientists isolated the gene for GFP and figured out how to insert it
into the DNA of other cells. There, it acts like a biochemical beacon, marking genetic modifications, or revealing the path 
of critical molecules. Scientists have used the glow of GFP
to watch cancer cells proliferate, track the development of Alzheimer's, and illuminate countless other
biological processes. Developing the tools and techniques
from GFP has netted three scientists
a Nobel Prize in 2008, and another three in 2014. But it's jellyfish who may be the most
successful organisms on Earth. Ancient fossils prove that jellyfish
have inhabited the seas for at least 500 million years, and maybe go back over 700 million. That's longer than any 
other multiorgan animal. And as other marine animals 
are struggling to survive in warmer and more acidic oceans, the jellyfish are thriving, and perhaps getting even more numerous. It doesn't hurt that some can lay
as many as 45,000 eggs in a single night. And there's some jellyfish 
whose survival strategy almost sounds like science fiction. When the immortal jellyfish is sick,
aging, or under stress, its struggling cells can change
their identity. The tiny bell and tentacles deteriorate and turn into an immature polyp that spawns brand new clones
of the parent. As far as we know, these are the only
animals who found a loophole when facing mortality. That's pretty sophisticated for species
that are 95% water and predate the dinosaurs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The explosive sting of some jellyfish exerts ____ times the pressure of Mike Tyson's strongest punch.
Options: A. 1/5, B. 1/2, C. 5, D. 550
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the body composition of jellyfish? Options: A. They are made up of 95% protein fibers., B. They are made up of 95% water held together by protein fibers., C. They are made up of 50% water and 50% protein fibers., D. They are made up of 100% water. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of the neural net in jellyfish? Options: A. To sense the ocean's currents and the touch of other animals., B. To control the movement of the jellyfish., C. To facilitate digestion., D. To regulate body temperature. Correct Option: None
Question 3: How do jellyfish consume food? Options: A. Through a typical digestive system with a mouth and anus., B. Through a hole in the underside of their bells, with nutrients absorbed by an inner layer of cells., C. By photosynthesis., D. By absorbing nutrients from the surrounding water. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is unique about the box jellyfish's visual system? Options: A. It has only two eyes., B. It has 24 eyes and can see color and form images., C. It has no eyes at all., D. It has eyes that can only detect light and dark. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of the nematocysts in jellyfish? Options: A. To capture prey and defend against predators., B. To facilitate movement., C. To regulate body temperature., D. To aid in digestion. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the biofluorescent compound found in some jellyfish? Options: A. Green fluorescent protein (GFP)., B. Blue fluorescent protein (BFP)., C. Red fluorescent protein (RFP)., D. Yellow fluorescent protein (YFP). Correct Option: None
Question 7: How have scientists used GFP in research? Options: A. To track the development of Alzheimer's disease., B. To study the behavior of jellyfish., C. To develop new medicines., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How long have jellyfish inhabited the oceans? Options: A. At least 100 million years., B. At least 500 million years., C. At least 1 billion years., D. At least 2 billion years. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is unique about the immortal jellyfish's survival strategy? Options: A. It can live forever without aging., B. It can change its cells into an immature polyp that spawns new clones., C. It can regenerate lost body parts., D. It can survive in extreme environments. Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why are jellyfish thriving in warmer and more acidic oceans? Options: A. Because they are immune to the effects of climate change., B. Because they can adapt quickly to changing environments., C. Because they can lay large numbers of eggs., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent, the most similar generated MCQ is not present. But we can find a question that is related to the sting of jellyfish.

The closest match is Question 5: What is the purpose of the nematocysts in jellyfish? Options: A. To capture prey and defend against predators., B. To facilitate movement., C. To regulate body temperature., D. To aid in digestion.

However, this question does not mention the pressure exerted by the sting. Therefore, it is not a direct match.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that there is no direct match, but the closest related question is Question 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
Some are longer than a blue whale. Others are barely larger 
than a grain of sand. One species unleashes one of
the most deadly venoms on Earth. Another holds a secret that's behind some 
of the greatest breakthroughs in biology. They've inhabited the ocean for at least
half a billion years, and they're still flourishing as the sea
changes around them. Jellyfish are soft-bodied sea creatures
that aren't really fish. They're part of a diverse team
of gelatinous zooplankton, zooplankton being animals that drift
in the ocean. There are more than 1,000 species
of jellyfish, and many others 
that are often mistaken for them. A noted feature of jellyfish 
is a translucent bell made of a soft delicate material
called mesoglea. Sandwiched between two layers of skin, the mesoglea is more than 95% water
held together by protein fibers. The jellyfish can contract and 
relax their bells to propel themselves. They don't have a brain or a spinal cord, but a neural net around the bell's

some remarkable abilities. One kind of box jellyfish has 24 eyes. Scientists think it can see color and form
images within its simple nervous system. Four of its eyes are curved 
upward on stalks. This allows the jellyfish to peer
through the surface of the water, looking for the canopy 
of the mangrove trees where it feeds. In fact, this may be one

lie coiled like poisonous harpoons. When they're triggered by contact,
they shoot with an explosive force. It exerts over 550 times the pressure
of Mike Tyson's strongest punch to inject venom into the victim. Some jellyfish stings barely tingle, but others cause severe skin damage. The venom of one box jellyfish
can kill a human in under five minutes, making it one of the most potent
poisons of any animal in the world. Other jellyfish superpowers 
are less lethal. One species of jellyfish glows green
when it's agitated, mostly thanks to a biofluorescent compound
called green fluorescent protein, or GFP. Scientists isolated the gene for GFP and figured out how to insert it
into the DNA of other cells. There, it acts like a biochemical beacon, marking genetic modifications, or revealing the path 
of critical molecules. Scientists have used the glow of GFP
to watch cancer cells proliferate, track the development of Alzheimer's, and illuminate countless other
biological processes. Developing the tools and techniques
from GFP has netted three scientists
a Nobel Prize in 2008, and another three in 2014. But it's jellyfish who may be the most
successful organisms on Earth. Ancient fossils prove that jellyfish
have inhabited the seas for at least 500 million years, and maybe go back over 700 million. That's longer than any

whose survival strategy almost sounds like science fiction. When the immortal jellyfish is sick,

their identity. The tiny bell and tentacles deteriorate and turn into an immature polyp that spawns brand new clones
of the parent. As far as we know, these are the only
animals who found a loophole when facing mortality. That's pretty sophisticated for species
that are 95% water and predate the dinosaurs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Some jellyfish have panorama vision with __________ eyes that allow them to look in 360 degrees.
Options: A. 4, B. 8, C. 24, D. 30
Correct Option: C

It has 24 eyes and can see color and form images., C. It has no eyes at all., D. It has eyes that can only detect light and dark.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it discusses the unique visual system of the box jellyfish, specifically mentioning the number of eyes (24) and its ability to see color and form images. The options also align with the ground truth MCQ, with option B being the correct answer.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
Some are longer than a blue whale. Others are barely larger 
than a grain of sand. One species unleashes one of
the most deadly venoms on Earth. Another holds a secret that's behind some 
of the greatest breakthroughs in biology. They've inhabited the ocean for at least
half a billion years, and they're still flourishing as the sea

that aren't really fish. They're part of a diverse team
of gelatinous zooplankton, zooplankton being animals that drift

relax their bells to propel themselves. They don't have a brain or a spinal cord, but a neural net around the bell's
inner margin forms a rudimentary nervous system that can sense the ocean's currents

some remarkable abilities. One kind of box jellyfish has 24 eyes. Scientists think it can see color and form
images within its simple nervous system. Four of its eyes are curved 
upward on stalks. This allows the jellyfish to peer
through the surface of the water, looking for the canopy 
of the mangrove trees where it feeds. In fact, this may be one

whose survival strategy almost sounds like science fiction. When the immortal jellyfish is sick,
aging, or under stress, its struggling cells can change
their identity. The tiny bell and tentacles deteriorate and turn into an immature polyp that spawns brand new clones
of the parent. As far as we know, these are the only
animals who found a loophole when facing mortality. That's pretty sophisticated for species
that are 95% water and predate the dinosaurs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 25, B. 55, C. 75, D. >95
Correct Option: D

Options: A. Cancer Research, B. AIDS research, C. Alzheimer's disease research, D. Skyscraper construction materials
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some are longer than a blue whale. Others are barely larger 
than a grain of sand. One species unleashes one of
the most deadly venoms on Earth. Another holds a secret that's behind some 
of the greatest breakthroughs in biology. They've inhabited the ocean for at least
half a billion years, and they're still flourishing as the sea
changes around them. Jellyfish are soft-bodied sea creatures
that aren't really fish. They're part of a diverse team
of gelatinous zooplankton, zooplankton being animals that drift
in the ocean. There are more than 1,000 species
of jellyfish, and many others 
that are often mistaken for them. A noted feature of jellyfish 
is a translucent bell made of a soft delicate material
called mesoglea. Sandwiched between two layers of skin, the mesoglea is more than 95% water
held together by protein fibers. The jellyfish can contract and 
relax their bells to propel themselves. They don't have a brain or a spinal cord, but a neural net around the bell's
inner margin forms a rudimentary nervous system that can sense the ocean's currents
and the touch of other animals. Jellyfish don't have typical 
digestive systems, either. These gelatinous carnivores consume 
plankton and other small sea creatures through a hole in the underside 
of their bells. The nutrients are absorbed by
an inner layer of cells with waste excreted back through
their mouths. But the jellyfish's relatively 
simple anatomy doesn't prevent it from having
some remarkable abilities. One kind of box jellyfish has 24 eyes. Scientists think it can see color and form
images within its simple nervous system. Four of its eyes are curved 
upward on stalks. This allows the jellyfish to peer
through the surface of the water, looking for the canopy 
of the mangrove trees where it feeds. In fact, this may be one 
of the only creatures with a 360-degree view of its environment. The jellyfish's sting, which helps it
capture prey and defend itself, is its most infamous calling card. In the jelly's epidermis, cells called nematocysts
lie coiled like poisonous harpoons. When they're triggered by contact,
they shoot with an explosive force. It exerts over 550 times the pressure
of Mike Tyson's strongest punch to inject venom into the victim. Some jellyfish stings barely tingle, but others cause severe skin damage. The venom of one box jellyfish
can kill a human in under five minutes, making it one of the most potent
poisons of any animal in the world. Other jellyfish superpowers 
are less lethal. One species of jellyfish glows green
when it's agitated, mostly thanks to a biofluorescent compound
called green fluorescent protein, or GFP. Scientists isolated the gene for GFP and figured out how to insert it
into the DNA of other cells. There, it acts like a biochemical beacon, marking genetic modifications, or revealing the path 
of critical molecules. Scientists have used the glow of GFP
to watch cancer cells proliferate, track the development of Alzheimer's, and illuminate countless other
biological processes. Developing the tools and techniques
from GFP has netted three scientists
a Nobel Prize in 2008, and another three in 2014. But it's jellyfish who may be the most
successful organisms on Earth. Ancient fossils prove that jellyfish
have inhabited the seas for at least 500 million years, and maybe go back over 700 million. That's longer than any 
other multiorgan animal. And as other marine animals 
are struggling to survive in warmer and more acidic oceans, the jellyfish are thriving, and perhaps getting even more numerous. It doesn't hurt that some can lay
as many as 45,000 eggs in a single night. And there's some jellyfish 
whose survival strategy almost sounds like science fiction. When the immortal jellyfish is sick,
aging, or under stress, its struggling cells can change
their identity. The tiny bell and tentacles deteriorate and turn into an immature polyp that spawns brand new clones
of the parent. As far as we know, these are the only
animals who found a loophole when facing mortality. That's pretty sophisticated for species
that are 95% water and predate the dinosaurs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Some jellyfish can lay up to __________ eggs per night.
Options: A. 100, B. 1,000, C. 10,000, D. 45,000
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the body composition of jellyfish? Options: A. They are made up of 95% protein fibers., B. They are made up of 95% water held together by protein fibers., C. They are made up of 50% water and 50% protein fibers., D. They are made up of 100% water. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of the neural net in jellyfish? Options: A. To sense the ocean's currents and the touch of other animals., B. To control the movement of the jellyfish., C. To facilitate digestion., D. To regulate body temperature. Correct Option: None
Question 3: How do jellyfish consume food? Options: A. Through a typical digestive system with a mouth and anus., B. Through a hole in the underside of their bells, with nutrients absorbed by an inner layer of cells., C. By photosynthesis., D. By absorbing nutrients from the surrounding water. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is unique about the box jellyfish's visual system? Options: A. It has only two eyes., B. It has 24 eyes and can see color and form images., C. It has no eyes at all., D. It has eyes that can only detect light and dark. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of the nematocysts in jellyfish? Options: A. To capture prey and defend against predators., B. To facilitate movement., C. To regulate body temperature., D. To aid in digestion. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the biofluorescent compound found in some jellyfish? Options: A. Green fluorescent protein (GFP)., B. Blue fluorescent protein (BFP)., C. Red fluorescent protein (RFP)., D. Yellow fluorescent protein (YFP). Correct Option: None
Question 7: How have scientists used GFP in research? Options: A. To track the development of Alzheimer's disease., B. To study the behavior of jellyfish., C. To develop new medicines., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How long have jellyfish inhabited the oceans? Options: A. At least 100 million years., B. At least 500 million years., C. At least 1 billion years., D. At least 2 billion years. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is unique about the immortal jellyfish's survival strategy? Options: A. It can live forever without aging., B. It can change its cells into an immature polyp that spawns new clones., C. It can regenerate lost body parts., D. It can survive in extreme environments. Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why are jellyfish thriving in warmer and more acidic oceans? Options: A. Because they are immune to the effects of climate change., B. Because they can adapt quickly to changing environments., C. Because they can lay large numbers of eggs., D. All of the above. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent of the questions, the most similar generated MCQ would be Question 10: "Why are jellyfish thriving in warmer and more acidic oceans?" Options: A. Because they are immune to the effects of climate change., B. Because they can adapt quickly to changing environments., C. Because they can lay large numbers of eggs., D. All of the above.

This question is related to the ground truth MCQ because it mentions the ability of jellyfish to lay large numbers of eggs, which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ (45,000 eggs per night). However, the generated MCQ is phrased differently and has different options.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some are longer than a blue whale. Others are barely larger 
than a grain of sand. One species unleashes one of
the most deadly venoms on Earth. Another holds a secret that's behind some 
of the greatest breakthroughs in biology. They've inhabited the ocean for at least
half a billion years, and they're still flourishing as the sea
changes around them. Jellyfish are soft-bodied sea creatures
that aren't really fish. They're part of a diverse team
of gelatinous zooplankton, zooplankton being animals that drift
in the ocean. There are more than 1,000 species
of jellyfish, and many others 
that are often mistaken for them. A noted feature of jellyfish 
is a translucent bell made of a soft delicate material
called mesoglea. Sandwiched between two layers of skin, the mesoglea is more than 95% water
held together by protein fibers. The jellyfish can contract and 
relax their bells to propel themselves. They don't have a brain or a spinal cord, but a neural net around the bell's
inner margin forms a rudimentary nervous system that can sense the ocean's currents
and the touch of other animals. Jellyfish don't have typical 
digestive systems, either. These gelatinous carnivores consume 
plankton and other small sea creatures through a hole in the underside 
of their bells. The nutrients are absorbed by
an inner layer of cells with waste excreted back through
their mouths. But the jellyfish's relatively 
simple anatomy doesn't prevent it from having
some remarkable abilities. One kind of box jellyfish has 24 eyes. Scientists think it can see color and form
images within its simple nervous system. Four of its eyes are curved 
upward on stalks. This allows the jellyfish to peer
through the surface of the water, looking for the canopy 
of the mangrove trees where it feeds. In fact, this may be one 
of the only creatures with a 360-degree view of its environment. The jellyfish's sting, which helps it
capture prey and defend itself, is its most infamous calling card. In the jelly's epidermis, cells called nematocysts
lie coiled like poisonous harpoons. When they're triggered by contact,
they shoot with an explosive force. It exerts over 550 times the pressure
of Mike Tyson's strongest punch to inject venom into the victim. Some jellyfish stings barely tingle, but others cause severe skin damage. The venom of one box jellyfish
can kill a human in under five minutes, making it one of the most potent
poisons of any animal in the world. Other jellyfish superpowers 
are less lethal. One species of jellyfish glows green
when it's agitated, mostly thanks to a biofluorescent compound
called green fluorescent protein, or GFP. Scientists isolated the gene for GFP and figured out how to insert it
into the DNA of other cells. There, it acts like a biochemical beacon, marking genetic modifications, or revealing the path 
of critical molecules. Scientists have used the glow of GFP
to watch cancer cells proliferate, track the development of Alzheimer's, and illuminate countless other
biological processes. Developing the tools and techniques
from GFP has netted three scientists
a Nobel Prize in 2008, and another three in 2014. But it's jellyfish who may be the most
successful organisms on Earth. Ancient fossils prove that jellyfish
have inhabited the seas for at least 500 million years, and maybe go back over 700 million. That's longer than any 
other multiorgan animal. And as other marine animals 
are struggling to survive in warmer and more acidic oceans, the jellyfish are thriving, and perhaps getting even more numerous. It doesn't hurt that some can lay
as many as 45,000 eggs in a single night. And there's some jellyfish 
whose survival strategy almost sounds like science fiction. When the immortal jellyfish is sick,
aging, or under stress, its struggling cells can change
their identity. The tiny bell and tentacles deteriorate and turn into an immature polyp that spawns brand new clones
of the parent. As far as we know, these are the only
animals who found a loophole when facing mortality. That's pretty sophisticated for species
that are 95% water and predate the dinosaurs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Jellyfish have one of the earliest nervous systems. It is called a neural __________ that weaves around the inner margin of the bell.
Options: A. Brain, B. Net, C. Cognition, D. Hippocampus
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Without water, a human can only
survive for about 100 hours. But there's a creature so resilient
that it can go without it for decades. This one millimeter animal can survive
both the hottest and coldest environments on Earth, and can even withstand high levels
of radiation. This is the tardigrade, and it's one of the toughest creatures
on Earth, even if it does look more like
a chubby, eight-legged gummy bear. Most organisms need water to survive. Water allows metabolism to occur, which is the process that drives
all the biochemical reactions that take place in cells. But creatures like the tardigrade,
also known as the water bear, get around this restriction
with a process called anhydrobiosis, from the Greek meaning
life without water. And however extraordinary,
tardigrades aren't alone. Bacteria, single-celled organisms called archaea, plants, and even other animals 
can all survive drying up. For many tardigrades, this requires that they go through 
something called a tun state. They curl up into a ball, pulling their head and eight legs
inside their body and wait until water returns. It's thought that as water
becomes scarce and tardigrades enter their tun state, they start synthesize special molecules, which fill the tardigrade's cells
to replace lost water by forming a matrix. Components of the cells that are
sensitive to dryness, like DNA, proteins, and membranes, get trapped in this matrix. It's thought that this keeps these
molecules locked in position to stop them from unfolding, breaking apart, or fusing together. Once the organism is rehydrated,
the matrix dissolves, leaving behind undamaged, 
functional cells. Beyond dryness, tardigrades can also
tolerate other extreme stresses: being frozen, heated up past the boiling point
of water, high levels of radiation, and even the vacuum of outer space. This has led to some erroneous speculation that tardigrades 
are extraterrestrial beings. While that's fun to think about, scientific evidence places their
origin firmly on Earth where they've evolved over time. In fact, this earthly evolution 
has given rise to over 1100 known species of tardigrades and there are probably many others
yet to be discovered. And because tardigrades are so hardy,
they exist just about everywhere. They live on every continent,
including Antarctica. And they're in diverse biomes
including deserts, ice sheets, the sea, fresh water, rainforests, and the highest mountain peaks. But you can find tardigrades
in the most ordinary places, too, like moss or lichen found in yards, parks, and forests. All you need to find them is a little
patience and a microscope. Scientists are now to trying to find out
whether tardigrades use the tun state, their anti-drying technique, to survive other stresses. If we can understand how they,
and other creatures, stabilize their sensitive 
biological molecules, perhaps we could apply this knowledge
to help us stabilize vaccines, or to develop stress-tolerant crops that 
can cope with Earth's changing climate. And by studying how tardigrades survive prolonged exposure 
to the vacuum of outer space, scientists can generate clues about
the environmental limits of life and how to safeguard astronauts. In the process, tardigrades could even
help us answer a critical question: could life survive on planets much
less hospitable than our own?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where are tardigrades normally found?
Options: A. Forests, B. Deserts, C. Ponds, D. Every continent and in diverse biomes
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How long can a human survive without water? Options: A. Several decades, B. About 100 hours, C. Several weeks, D. Several months Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the process that allows creatures like tardigrades to survive without water? Options: A. Anhydrobiosis, B. Hydrobiosis, C. Metabolism, D. Photosynthesis Correct Option: None
Question 3: What do tardigrades do to survive in extreme environments? Options: A. They migrate to a different location, B. They hibernate, C. They curl up into a ball and enter a tun state, D. They change their diet Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the special molecules synthesized by tardigrades in their tun state? Options: A. To provide energy for the organism, B. To replace lost water by forming a matrix, C. To protect the organism from predators, D. To regulate the organism's body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the result of the matrix dissolving when the tardigrade is rehydrated? Options: A. The cells are damaged and non-functional, B. The cells are undamaged and functional, C. The cells are destroyed and the organism dies, D. The cells are modified and the organism changes its behavior Correct Option: None
Question 6: What are some of the extreme stresses that tardigrades can tolerate? Options: A. High levels of radiation, extreme temperatures, and high pressures, B. High levels of radiation, being frozen, and the vacuum of outer space, C. Extreme temperatures, high pressures, and high salinity, D. High levels of radiation, extreme temperatures, and high salinity Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many known species of tardigrades are there? Options: A. Over 100, B. Over 500, C. Over 1100, D. Over 2000 Correct Option: None
Question 8: Where can tardigrades be found? Options: A. Only in extreme environments such as deserts and ice sheets, B. Only in aquatic environments such as oceans and lakes, C. In diverse biomes including deserts, ice sheets, the sea, fresh water, rainforests, and the highest mountain peaks, D. Only in terrestrial environments such as forests and grasslands Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one of the potential applications of studying how tardigrades survive extreme stresses? Options: A. Developing new medicines, B. Developing stress-tolerant crops that can cope with Earth's changing climate, C. Developing new technologies for space exploration, D. Understanding the evolution of life on Earth Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is one of the critical questions that studying tardigrades could help answer? Options: A. Could life survive on planets much less hospitable than our own?, B. How did life originate on Earth?, C. What are the environmental limits of life?, D. How can we develop new technologies for space exploration? Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which is to ask about the typical locations or environments where tardigrades can be found. The options for Question 8 also closely match the options for the ground truth MCQ, with option C in Question 8 being very similar to option D in the ground truth MCQ. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 8.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2

Options: A. Curls up into a ball like structure known as a ‘tun’, B. Extends its legs and goes rigid, C. Nothing, they just stop moving, D. Flatten themselves out
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Without water, a human can only
survive for about 100 hours. But there's a creature so resilient
that it can go without it for decades. This one millimeter animal can survive
both the hottest and coldest environments on Earth, and can even withstand high levels
of radiation. This is the tardigrade, and it's one of the toughest creatures
on Earth, even if it does look more like
a chubby, eight-legged gummy bear. Most organisms need water to survive. Water allows metabolism to occur, which is the process that drives

also known as the water bear, get around this restriction
with a process called anhydrobiosis, from the Greek meaning
life without water. And however extraordinary,
tardigrades aren't alone. Bacteria, single-celled organisms called archaea, plants, and even other animals

becomes scarce and tardigrades enter their tun state, they start synthesize special molecules, which fill the tardigrade's cells
to replace lost water by forming a matrix. Components of the cells that are
sensitive to dryness, like DNA, proteins, and membranes, get trapped in this matrix. It's thought that this keeps these
molecules locked in position to stop them from unfolding, breaking apart, or fusing together. Once the organism is rehydrated,
the matrix dissolves, leaving behind undamaged, 
functional cells. Beyond dryness, tardigrades can also
tolerate other extreme stresses: being frozen, heated up past the boiling point
of water, high levels of radiation, and even the vacuum of outer space. This has led to some erroneous speculation that tardigrades 
are extraterrestrial beings. While that's fun to think about, scientific evidence places their

has given rise to over 1100 known species of tardigrades and there are probably many others

including deserts, ice sheets, the sea, fresh water, rainforests, and the highest mountain peaks. But you can find tardigrades
in the most ordinary places, too, like moss or lichen found in yards, parks, and forests. All you need to find them is a little

whether tardigrades use the tun state, their anti-drying technique, to survive other stresses. If we can understand how they,
and other creatures, stabilize their sensitive 
biological molecules, perhaps we could apply this knowledge
to help us stabilize vaccines, or to develop stress-tolerant crops that 
can cope with Earth's changing climate. And by studying how tardigrades survive prolonged exposure 
to the vacuum of outer space, scientists can generate clues about
the environmental limits of life and how to safeguard astronauts. In the process, tardigrades could even
help us answer a critical question: could life survive on planets much
less hospitable than our own?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many species of tardigrades have been discovered?
Options: A. 1, B. About 100, C. About 15,000, D. About 1,200
Correct Option: D

To replace lost water by forming a matrix, C. To protect the organism from predators, D. To regulate the organism's body temperature Correct Option: None

The cells are destroyed and the organism dies, D. The cells are modified and the organism changes its behavior Correct Option: None

High levels of radiation, being frozen, and the vacuum of outer space, C. Extreme temperatures, high pressures, and high salinity, D. High levels of radiation, extreme temperatures, and high salinity Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Without water, a human can only
survive for about 100 hours. But there's a creature so resilient
that it can go without it for decades. This one millimeter animal can survive
both the hottest and coldest environments on Earth, and can even withstand high levels
of radiation. This is the tardigrade, and it's one of the toughest creatures
on Earth, even if it does look more like
a chubby, eight-legged gummy bear. Most organisms need water to survive. Water allows metabolism to occur, which is the process that drives
all the biochemical reactions that take place in cells. But creatures like the tardigrade,
also known as the water bear, get around this restriction
with a process called anhydrobiosis, from the Greek meaning
life without water. And however extraordinary,
tardigrades aren't alone. Bacteria, single-celled organisms called archaea, plants, and even other animals 
can all survive drying up. For many tardigrades, this requires that they go through 
something called a tun state. They curl up into a ball, pulling their head and eight legs
inside their body and wait until water returns. It's thought that as water
becomes scarce and tardigrades enter their tun state, they start synthesize special molecules, which fill the tardigrade's cells
to replace lost water by forming a matrix. Components of the cells that are
sensitive to dryness, like DNA, proteins, and membranes, get trapped in this matrix. It's thought that this keeps these
molecules locked in position to stop them from unfolding, breaking apart, or fusing together. Once the organism is rehydrated,
the matrix dissolves, leaving behind undamaged, 
functional cells. Beyond dryness, tardigrades can also
tolerate other extreme stresses: being frozen, heated up past the boiling point
of water, high levels of radiation, and even the vacuum of outer space. This has led to some erroneous speculation that tardigrades 
are extraterrestrial beings. While that's fun to think about, scientific evidence places their
origin firmly on Earth where they've evolved over time. In fact, this earthly evolution 
has given rise to over 1100 known species of tardigrades and there are probably many others
yet to be discovered. And because tardigrades are so hardy,
they exist just about everywhere. They live on every continent,
including Antarctica. And they're in diverse biomes
including deserts, ice sheets, the sea, fresh water, rainforests, and the highest mountain peaks. But you can find tardigrades
in the most ordinary places, too, like moss or lichen found in yards, parks, and forests. All you need to find them is a little
patience and a microscope. Scientists are now to trying to find out
whether tardigrades use the tun state, their anti-drying technique, to survive other stresses. If we can understand how they,
and other creatures, stabilize their sensitive 
biological molecules, perhaps we could apply this knowledge
to help us stabilize vaccines, or to develop stress-tolerant crops that 
can cope with Earth's changing climate. And by studying how tardigrades survive prolonged exposure 
to the vacuum of outer space, scientists can generate clues about
the environmental limits of life and how to safeguard astronauts. In the process, tardigrades could even
help us answer a critical question: could life survive on planets much
less hospitable than our own?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How is it thought that tardigrades protect their cellular components when they dry out?
Options: A. They do not have to; their cellular components are just tougher than normal, B. They produce molecules that form a protective matrix within their cells, C. They do not protect their cellular components at all; instead they repair the damage after they are rehydrated, D. The do not protect their cellular components; instead they make new undamaged components once they are rehydrated
Correct Option: B

The cells are destroyed and the organism dies, D. The cells are modified and the organism changes its behavior Correct Option: None

High levels of radiation, being frozen, and the vacuum of outer space, C. Extreme temperatures, high pressures, and high salinity, D. High levels of radiation, extreme temperatures, and high salinity Correct Option: None

In diverse biomes including deserts, ice sheets, the sea, fresh water, rainforests, and the highest mountain peaks, D. Understanding the evolution of life on Earth Correct Option: None

How did life originate on Earth?, C. What are the environmental limits of life?, D. How can we develop new technologies for space exploration? Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: What is the purpose of the special molecules synthesized by tardigrades in their tun state? 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions are asking about how tardigrades protect their cellular components when they dry out, and both questions have an option that mentions the formation of a matrix to replace lost water.

and other creatures, stabilize their sensitive 
biological molecules, perhaps we could apply this knowledge
to help us stabilize vaccines, or to develop stress-tolerant crops that

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Figs are one of my favorite foods. They're sweet and floral, and there's something
about the texture that I find so delightful—the outside is soft, but the seeds in the middle
give you this totally satisfying crunch. But it turns out that many species of figs
contain the bodies of dead wasps. I'm Anna and this is Gross Science. Figs aren't exactly your typical fruit. You can think of them as packages that contain
all of the fig tree’s flowers within them. But if the flowers are trapped inside the
fig how do they get pollinated? Well, that's where fig wasps come in. In most species, pregnant female fig wasps
carrying pollen are attracted to young figs. They enter through a tiny opening at the fig’s
bottom that’s highly selective—it usually only lets in the exact species of wasps that
pollinate it. But, even the pollinators have a hard time
getting in. Most lose their wings and antennae in the
process. The wasp’s goal is to find a home for her
babies. And the perfect home is inside the fig’s
female flowers—those are the ones that would produce seeds if they were fertilized. So, the mama wasp drops a fertilized egg inside
as many of the female flowers as she can—sometimes, up to a few hundred. But she can't get to all of them. Along the way, she winds up fertilizing the
rest of the flowers with the fig pollen she's carrying, and those flowers begin developing
seeds. Once the wasp is finished laying eggs, she
usually dies inside the fig. Each baby wasp begins to grow, encased in
a protective structure that the plant forms called a gall. The male wasps mature first. When they emerge, they find the galls of the
female wasps, many of whom are their sisters, poke inside, and impregnate them before they've
even hatched! Then, the males die inside the fig, but not
before boring tiny holes through the fig’s skin. When the females do emerge, the fig has just
started producing pollen. The female wasps pick up some of that pollen
before making their way through the holes their brothers drilled, and go off to find
a new fig to start the cycle again. But the story's not over. At this point, our fig’s seeds are finally
mature and ready to be planted. And that happens when the ripe fig is eaten
by animals, which poop out the seeds, spreading fig plants far and wide. Of course, humans eat figs, too. So, when you bite into a fig are you actually
eating the bodies of dead wasps? Well, if you’re getting your figs from the
supermarket, then most likely not. See, humans and figs have a really long history—we’ve
probably been domesticating them for over 11,000 years. So, while there are over 750 species in the
world, most of the figs we eat are a species called the “common fig,” which humans
have had a huge hand in creating. In fact, some common figs are seedless and
don’t require pollination at all. Other varieties of common fig do need to be
pollinated, but have separate male and female trees, and we only eat fruits from the female
ones. I’ll put a link in the description to a
great explanation of how common fig pollination happens, but long story short, female wasps
can only manage to lay eggs in the the figs from male trees, not female ones. But they can’t tell the difference between
the two types of trees. So, if a wasp does enter a female fruit, she’ll
pollinate it, and either manage to escape or die inside the fig. And then that fig might make it to your table. Frankly, one wasp here and there isn’t enough
to deter me from eating these things. But if you're still feeling squeamish, just
think about it this way: by eating that fig, you're benefitting from a complex and in my
view, beautiful partnership—or, what’s called a “mutualism”— between two very
different species. One that’s been delicately crafted by around
90 million years of evolution. And that certainly whets my appetite—at
least for curiosity, if not for dinner. MMMM! But also ew.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Wasps crawl inside figs because...
Options: A. The flowers are actually on the inside of a fig, B. They can hide their eggs there from predators, C. Fig juice is similar to honey
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the texture of a fig? Options: A. It's crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside., B. It's soft on the outside and crunchy on the inside due to seeds., C. It's smooth on the outside and jelly-like on the inside., D. It's rough on the outside and smooth on the inside. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What role do female fig wasps play in the pollination of figs? Options: A. They enter the fig through a tiny opening and lay eggs in the male flowers., B. They enter the fig through a tiny opening and lay eggs in the female flowers, while also pollinating the rest of the flowers., C. They enter the fig through a large opening and lay eggs in the female flowers., D. They do not play a role in the pollination of figs. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the female fig wasp after she lays eggs inside the fig? Options: A. She escapes through a tiny hole and finds another fig to pollinate., B. She dies inside the fig., C. She is trapped inside the fig forever., D. She is eaten by the fig. Correct Option: None
Question 4: How do male fig wasps contribute to the life cycle of fig wasps? Options: A. They pollinate the female flowers and lay eggs in the male flowers., B. They emerge from their galls, impregnate the female wasps, and then die inside the fig., C. They do not contribute to the life cycle of fig wasps., D. They only pollinate the male flowers. Correct Option: None
Question 5: How are fig seeds dispersed? Options: A. By wind., B. By water., C. By animals eating the figs and then pooping out the seeds., D. By humans planting the seeds. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is unique about the "common fig" species? Options: A. It requires pollination by fig wasps., B. It does not require pollination and is often seedless., C. It is only eaten by animals., D. It is only eaten by humans. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why are fig wasps unable to lay eggs in the figs of female "common fig" trees? Options: A. Because the figs are too small., B. Because the figs are too large., C. Because the wasps can't tell the difference between male and female trees, and can only lay eggs in male trees., D. Because the wasps are not attracted to female trees. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the relationship between figs and fig wasps called? Options: A. Symbiosis., B. Mutualism., C. Parasitism., D. Commensalism. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How long have humans been domesticating figs? Options: A. Over 1,000 years., B. Over 5,000 years., C. Over 11,000 years., D. Over 20,000 years. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the result of the partnership between figs and fig wasps? Options: A. The production of seeds that are not viable., B. The production of fruit that is not edible., C. The production of seeds that can be dispersed and grow into new fig plants., D. The production of wasps that are not able to pollinate. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the wording of the question is different, the intent and content of Question 2 are similar to the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks why wasps crawl inside figs, and the correct answer is that the flowers are actually on the inside of a fig. Question 2 asks about the role of female fig wasps in the pollination of figs, and the correct answer (if it were marked) would be that they enter the fig through a tiny opening and lay eggs in the female flowers, while also pollinating the rest of the flowers. This implies that the wasps crawl inside the figs because the flowers are inside, which matches the intent of the ground truth MCQ.

However, it's worth noting that the options provided for Question 2 do not exactly match the options of the ground truth MCQ, and the correct answer is not marked. If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based solely on the provided options, I would say that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. But based on question intent and content, Question 2 is the closest match.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: For how long have humans been cultivating figs?
Options: A. 60 years, B. 200 years, C. 11,000 years, D. 43,000 years

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the texture of a fig? Options: A. It's crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside., B. It's soft on the outside and crunchy on the inside due to seeds., C. It's smooth on the outside and jelly-like on the inside., D. It's rough on the outside and smooth on the inside. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What role do female fig wasps play in the pollination of figs? Options: A. They enter the fig through a tiny opening and lay eggs in the male flowers., B. They enter the fig through a tiny opening and lay eggs in the female flowers, while also pollinating the rest of the flowers., C. They enter the fig through a large opening and lay eggs in the female flowers., D. They do not play a role in the pollination of figs. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What happens to the female fig wasp after she lays eggs inside the fig? Options: A. She escapes through a tiny hole and finds another fig to pollinate., B. She dies inside the fig., C. She is trapped inside the fig forever., D. She is eaten by the fig. Correct Option: None
Question 4: How do male fig wasps contribute to the life cycle of fig wasps? Options: A. They pollinate the female flowers and lay eggs in the male flowers., B. They emerge from their galls, impregnate the female wasps, and then die inside the fig., C. They do not contribute to the life cycle of fig wasps., D. They only pollinate the male flowers. Correct Option: None
Question 5: How are fig seeds dispersed? Options: A. By wind., B. By water., C. By animals eating the figs and then pooping out the seeds., D. By humans planting the seeds. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is unique about the "common fig" species? Options: A. It requires pollination by fig wasps., B. It does not require pollination and is often seedless., C. It is only eaten by animals., D. It is only eaten by humans. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why are fig wasps unable to lay eggs in the figs of female "common fig" trees? Options: A. Because the figs are too small., B. Because the figs are too large., C. Because the wasps can't tell the difference between male and female trees, and can only lay eggs in male trees., D. Because the wasps are not attracted to female trees. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the relationship between figs and fig wasps called? Options: A. Symbiosis., B. Mutualism., C. Parasitism., D. Commensalism. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How long have humans been domesticating figs? Options: A. Over 1,000 years., B. Over 5,000 years., C. Over 11,000 years., D. Over 20,000 years. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the result of the partnership between figs and fig wasps? Options: A. The production of seeds that are not viable., B. The production of fruit that is not edible., C. The production of seeds that can be dispersed and grow into new fig plants., D. The production of wasps that are not able to pollinate. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In mythological ancient Greece, soaring above Crete on wings made
from wax and feathers, Icarus, the son of Daedalus,
defied the laws of both man and nature. Ignoring the warnings of his father,
he rose higher and higher. To witnesses on the ground,
he looked like a god, and as he peered down from above,
he felt like one, too. But, in mythological ancient Greece, the line that separated god from man
was absolute and the punishment for mortals
who attempted to cross it was severe. Such was the case for Icarus and Daedalus. Years before Icarus was born, his father Daedalus was highly regarded
as a genius inventor, craftsman, and sculptor in his homeland of Athens. He invented carpentry
and all the tools used for it. He designed the first bathhouse and the first dance floor. He made sculptures so lifelike
that Hercules mistook them for actual men. Though skilled and celebrated,
Daedalus was egotistical and jealous. Worried that his nephew
was a more skillful craftsman, Daedalus murdered him. As punishment, Daedalus was banished
from Athens and made his way to Crete. Preceded by his storied reputation, Daedalus was welcomed 
with open arms by Crete's King Minos. There, acting as the palace 
technical advisor, Daedalus continued to push the boundaries. For the king's children, he made mechanically animated toys
that seemed alive. He invented the ship's sail and mast,
which gave humans control over the wind. With every creation, Daedalus challenged
human limitations that had so far kept mortals
separate from gods, until finally, he broke right through. King Minos's wife, Pasiphaë,
had been cursed by the god Poseidon to fall in love
with the king's prized bull. Under this spell, she asked Daedalus
to help her seduce it. With characteristic audacity, he agreed. Daedalus constructed a hollow
wooden cow so realistic that it fooled the bull. With Pasiphaë hiding inside
Daedalus's creation, she conceived and gave birth
to the half-human half-bull minotaur. This, of course, enraged the king who blamed Daedalus for enabling
such a horrible perversion of natural law. As punishment, Daedalus was forced
to construct an inescapable labyrinth beneath the palace for the minotaur. When it was finished, Minos then
imprisoned Daedalus and his only son Icarus within the top of the tallest tower
on the island where they were to remain 
for the rest of their lives. But Daedalus was still a genius inventor. While observing the birds
that circled his prison, the means for escape became clear. He and Icarus would fly away
from their prison as only birds or gods could do. Using feathers from the flocks
that perched on the tower, and the wax from candles, Daedalus constructed two pairs
of giant wings. As he strapped the wings
to his son Icarus, he gave a warning: flying too near the ocean 
would dampen the wings and make them too heavy to use. Flying too near the sun, the heat would melt the wax
and the wings would disintegrate. In either case, they surely would die. Therefore, the key to their escape
would be in keeping to the middle. With the instructions clear,
both men leapt from the tower. They were the first mortals ever to fly. While Daedalus stayed carefully
to the midway course, Icarus was overwhelmed
with the ecstasy of flight and overcome with the feeling of
divine power that came with it. Daedalus could only watch in horror
as Icarus ascended higher and higher, powerless to change his son's dire fate. When the heat from the sun melted
the wax on his wings, Icarus fell from the sky. Just as Daedalus had many times ignored the consequences of defying 
the natural laws of mortal men in the service of his ego, Icarus was also carried away
by his own hubris. In the end, both men paid for their departure 
from the path of moderation dearly, Icarus with his life and Daedalus with his regret.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Daedalus was the father of Icarus and best described as a(n) ____.
Options: A. Inventor, B. Sculptor, C. Craftsman, D. A and b only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the main character in the mythological story of ancient Greece? Options: A. Hercules, B. Daedalus, C. Icarus, D. King Minos Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was Daedalus's profession in his homeland of Athens? Options: A. He was a king., B. He was a god., C. He was a genius inventor, craftsman, and sculptor., D. He was a farmer. Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why was Daedalus banished from Athens? Options: A. He was too skilled and celebrated., B. He was egotistical and jealous, and murdered his nephew., C. He was poor and unskilled., D. He was a foreigner. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What did Daedalus create for King Minos's children? Options: A. Mechanically animated toys that seemed alive., B. A hollow wooden cow., C. A ship's sail and mast., D. A labyrinth. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the curse that Pasiphaë, King Minos's wife, was under? Options: A. She was cursed to fall in love with Daedalus., B. She was cursed to fall in love with the king's prized bull., C. She was cursed to hate her husband., D. She was cursed to be childless. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What did Daedalus construct to help Pasiphaë seduce the bull? Options: A. A hollow wooden cow., B. A ship's sail and mast., C. A labyrinth., D. Mechanically animated toys. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the punishment for Daedalus after he helped Pasiphaë seduce the bull? Options: A. He was forced to construct an inescapable labyrinth., B. He was banished from Crete., C. He was imprisoned in the top of the tallest tower., D. Both A and C. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did Daedalus plan to escape from the tower with his son Icarus? Options: A. By digging a tunnel., B. By building a bridge., C. By flying away using wings made of feathers and wax., D. By swimming away. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the warning that Daedalus gave to Icarus before they flew away? Options: A. To fly as high as possible., B. To fly as low as possible., C. To keep to the middle and avoid flying too near the ocean or the sun., D. To follow the wind direction. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the cause of Icarus's death? Options: A. He flew too near the ocean and his wings became too heavy., B. He flew too near the sun and the wax on his wings melted., C. He was attacked by a bird., D. He fell from the tower. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the options and the phrasing of the question are not identical, the intent and content of Question 2 are closest to the ground truth MCQ. Question 2 asks about Daedalus's profession in Athens, and the correct answer (although not explicitly provided) would be "C. He was a genius inventor, craftsman, and sculptor," which aligns with the correct option "E. All of the above" in the ground truth MCQ.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

by his own hubris. In the end, both men paid for their departure 
from the path of moderation dearly, Icarus with his life and Daedalus with his regret.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What warning was given to Icarus?
Options: A. Don’t fly too close to the sun., B. Don’t fly low near the ocean., C. Stay in the middle between the sky and the sea., D. A and b only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the main character in the mythological story of ancient Greece? Options: A. Hercules, B. Daedalus, C. Icarus, D. King Minos Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was Daedalus's profession in his homeland of Athens? Options: A. He was a king., B. He was a god., C. He was a genius inventor, craftsman, and sculptor., D. He was a farmer. Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why was Daedalus banished from Athens? Options: A. He was too skilled and celebrated., B. He was egotistical and jealous, and murdered his nephew., C. He was poor and unskilled., D. He was a foreigner. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What did Daedalus create for King Minos's children? Options: A. Mechanically animated toys that seemed alive., B. A hollow wooden cow., C. A ship's sail and mast., D. A labyrinth. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the curse that Pasiphaë, King Minos's wife, was under? Options: A. She was cursed to fall in love with Daedalus., B. She was cursed to fall in love with the king's prized bull., C. She was cursed to hate her husband., D. She was cursed to be childless. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What did Daedalus construct to help Pasiphaë seduce the bull? Options: A. A hollow wooden cow., B. A ship's sail and mast., C. A labyrinth., D. Mechanically animated toys. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the punishment for Daedalus after he helped Pasiphaë seduce the bull? Options: A. He was forced to construct an inescapable labyrinth., B. He was banished from Crete., C. He was imprisoned in the top of the tallest tower., D. Both A and C. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did Daedalus plan to escape from the tower with his son Icarus? Options: A. By digging a tunnel., B. By building a bridge., C. By flying away using wings made of feathers and wax., D. By swimming away. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the warning that Daedalus gave to Icarus before they flew away? Options: A. To fly as high as possible., B. To fly as low as possible., C. To keep to the middle and avoid flying too near the ocean or the sun., D. To follow the wind direction. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the cause of Icarus's death? Options: A. He flew too near the ocean and his wings became too heavy., B. He flew too near the sun and the wax on his wings melted., C. He was attacked by a bird., D. He fell from the tower. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the warning given to Icarus before flying. The options also match the content of the ground truth MCQ, specifically option C, which states "To keep to the middle and avoid flying too near the ocean or the sun." This is equivalent to the correct option E in the ground truth MCQ, "All of the above," which includes the warnings to not fly too close to the sun, not fly low near the ocean, and stay in the middle between the sky and the sea.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In mythological ancient Greece, soaring above Crete on wings made
from wax and feathers, Icarus, the son of Daedalus,
defied the laws of both man and nature. Ignoring the warnings of his father,
he rose higher and higher. To witnesses on the ground,
he looked like a god, and as he peered down from above,
he felt like one, too. But, in mythological ancient Greece, the line that separated god from man
was absolute and the punishment for mortals
who attempted to cross it was severe. Such was the case for Icarus and Daedalus. Years before Icarus was born, his father Daedalus was highly regarded
as a genius inventor, craftsman, and sculptor in his homeland of Athens. He invented carpentry
and all the tools used for it. He designed the first bathhouse and the first dance floor. He made sculptures so lifelike
that Hercules mistook them for actual men. Though skilled and celebrated,
Daedalus was egotistical and jealous. Worried that his nephew
was a more skillful craftsman, Daedalus murdered him. As punishment, Daedalus was banished
from Athens and made his way to Crete. Preceded by his storied reputation, Daedalus was welcomed 
with open arms by Crete's King Minos. There, acting as the palace 
technical advisor, Daedalus continued to push the boundaries. For the king's children, he made mechanically animated toys
that seemed alive. He invented the ship's sail and mast,
which gave humans control over the wind. With every creation, Daedalus challenged
human limitations that had so far kept mortals
separate from gods, until finally, he broke right through. King Minos's wife, Pasiphaë,
had been cursed by the god Poseidon to fall in love
with the king's prized bull. Under this spell, she asked Daedalus
to help her seduce it. With characteristic audacity, he agreed. Daedalus constructed a hollow
wooden cow so realistic that it fooled the bull. With Pasiphaë hiding inside
Daedalus's creation, she conceived and gave birth
to the half-human half-bull minotaur. This, of course, enraged the king who blamed Daedalus for enabling
such a horrible perversion of natural law. As punishment, Daedalus was forced
to construct an inescapable labyrinth beneath the palace for the minotaur. When it was finished, Minos then
imprisoned Daedalus and his only son Icarus within the top of the tallest tower
on the island where they were to remain 
for the rest of their lives. But Daedalus was still a genius inventor. While observing the birds
that circled his prison, the means for escape became clear. He and Icarus would fly away
from their prison as only birds or gods could do. Using feathers from the flocks
that perched on the tower, and the wax from candles, Daedalus constructed two pairs
of giant wings. As he strapped the wings
to his son Icarus, he gave a warning: flying too near the ocean 
would dampen the wings and make them too heavy to use. Flying too near the sun, the heat would melt the wax
and the wings would disintegrate. In either case, they surely would die. Therefore, the key to their escape
would be in keeping to the middle. With the instructions clear,
both men leapt from the tower. They were the first mortals ever to fly. While Daedalus stayed carefully
to the midway course, Icarus was overwhelmed
with the ecstasy of flight and overcome with the feeling of
divine power that came with it. Daedalus could only watch in horror
as Icarus ascended higher and higher, powerless to change his son's dire fate. When the heat from the sun melted
the wax on his wings, Icarus fell from the sky. Just as Daedalus had many times ignored the consequences of defying 
the natural laws of mortal men in the service of his ego, Icarus was also carried away
by his own hubris. In the end, both men paid for their departure 
from the path of moderation dearly, Icarus with his life and Daedalus with his regret.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: As Daedalus watched Icarus fly toward the sun, he felt ____.
Options: A. Pride about his invention, B. Divine power, C. Helplessness, D. Foolishness
Correct Option: C

Question 6: What did Daedalus construct to help Pasiphaë seduce the bull? Options: A. A hollow wooden cow., B. A ship's sail and mast., C. A labyrinth., D. Mechanically animated toys. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the punishment for Daedalus after he helped Pasiphaë seduce the bull? Options: A. He was forced to construct an inescapable labyrinth., B. He was banished from Crete., C. He was imprisoned in the top of the tallest tower., D. Both A and C. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did Daedalus plan to escape from the tower with his son Icarus? Options: A. By digging a tunnel., B. By building a bridge., C. By flying away using wings made of feathers and wax., D. By swimming away. Correct Option: None
